top_comment.text:
I have to defend both Stanford and Michigan to some extent here.

First off, even as a Michigan grad, it's impressive what Stanford does with 
their football program. They exclusively recruit players that are good to 
great students. I know people find this hard to believe, but it's truly 
impressive. Many of the players that they have signed recently are 3.5+ GPA 
guys and 25+ ACT guys. Pretty good for elite athletes.

As far as Michigan, we have recently tried to up our standards as well to 
ensure that our team has more stability and less players unable to compete 
academically. As a result, we have recruited against Stanford often, which 
is how I came to understand how rare an offer from Stanford is unless you 
have great academics. Not every player we've signed has been a genius, 
don't get me wrong, but many have been at or near the top of their class in 
high school.

Additionally, Michigan's basketball team has had a perfect graduation rate 
recently (tops in the nation), with many of the players studying business, 
engineering, and the like.

I know Cenk was just pulling names out of nowhere, but he may have picked 
bad examples by random chance, as these two schools actually do care to an 
extent. Again, I will not claim that every bball/fball player at UM is a 
great student, but far more are than you'd think (at least on the team 
now). Stanford though, is one heck of a smart football program.﻿

top_comment.text:
All right, I'm confused.  Every college football athlete that goes pro 
(NFL) is required to take an IQ test called the Wonderlic.  It's not really 
an IQ test, per se, but it's a general knowledge and aptitude test, and 
it's pretty intense.  50 questions in 12 minutes (~14.5 seconds per 
question), and your score is just how many you answered correctly.  The 
average person will get 20 right, which is typically where an NFLer falls.

My issue with this is, if these athletes can barely read, how can they 
read, comprehend, and answer the questions quick enough not to score well 
below 20?  Granted, some do, but some score very high, and most score 
between 16-26 (close to average).

And it's not like the Wonderlic is a baby's test.  It's been peer-reviewed 
by the APA and found worthy of use in other fields.  ...I just don't get 
it.﻿

This is one of a few stories I've heard of this week that makes me stop 
to wonder, what exactly is wrong with stereotyping? Where's there's smoke 
there's usually fire and, surprise, surprise; Jocks are meatheads. Who 
knew?﻿
top_comment.author: Dillan Evans

comments.text:
It's not that athletes are more likely to be stupid. There are a few 
factors at play:
- The smartest athletes choose education over sports. I could have played 
DII college soccer, but I chose to focus on academics, instead. Best choice 
I ever made. The time commitment for sports is enormous; few people can do 
well in both.
- Related to the above, bad students when they're young are often steered 
preferentially away from academics. Then they have no hope of catching up, 
even if they aren't really that stupid.
- Colleges are going for the best athletes, regardless of intelligence, so 
even if all other factors were level, they'd end up with plenty of 
meatheads. That's just a matter of sampling from a different cross-section 
of society than they do for their actual students.
comments.author: iamihop

comments.text:
Because there are certain stereotypes that don't hold up to close scrutiny 
and analysis.
comments.author: martolives

top_comment.text:
Education should use an ongoing assessment system, with a final exam that 
only counts for a certain % of the student's grade.  This will take the 
laziness from those who doss all year and cram and ace their finals.  It 
will highlight problems very early.  And best of all, it teaches kids what 
it will be like in the workplace where their performance will also be under 
constant evaluation.
But ofc, this would involve effort and expense to set up and do, so could 
be a while.....﻿
